page.title: 05HATFIELD HOUSE
page.content:
will be able to see grain being ground into flour at Hatfield once again.
HATFIELD HOUSE Before Hatfield House there was Hatfield Palace. It was built on land which was at first called Bishop's Hatfield because it was owned by the Bishop of Ely. Later it housed Henry VIII's children. Elizabeth was here when she heard she was to be Queen. After Elizabeth I's death her first minister, Robert Cecil, the First Earl of Salisbury, began the present Hatfield House. To provide building material the old palace was demolished, except for the Great Hall with its impressive roof timbers. The plan of the new house was in the shape of an E in honour of Elizabeth. It stands in l300 acres with a Great Hall of panelling and tapestries.
